gurmukhi: qau lig sRI piq Awp kupXo sr BUpiq ky aur mY iek mwirE ] eyk hI bwn ko qwn qbY ieh swrQI ko pRqAMg pHwirE ]
transliteration: Tau Lag(i) Sripat(i) Aap Koupyo Sar Bhoopat(i) Ke Ur Mai Ik Maario|| Ek Hibaan Ko Taan Tabai Eh Saarthiko Prat-an Prahaario||
translation: Till that time, Krishna, in great ire, shot an arrow in the heart of the king; now he, pulling his bow discharged an arrow towards the charioteer;

gurmukhi: BUpiq Awgy hI hoq BXo rn BUmih qy trXo pg twirE ] sUr srwhq By sB hI jsu XoN muK qy kib sXwm aucwirE ]1644]
transliteration: Bhoopat(i) Aage Hihot Bhayo Ran Bhaamah(i) Te Daryo Pag Taario|| Soor Saraahat Bhe Sabh Hijas(u) Yon Moukh Te Kabi Syaam Ouchaario||1644||
translation: Now the king advanced forward and his feet slipped in the battlefield; the poet says that all the warriors began to eulogise this war.1644.

gurmukhi: sRI hir ko Aivlok kY Awnn ieau kih kY niRp bwq sunweI ] CUt rhI AlkY kit lau aupmw muK kI brnI nhI jweI ]
transliteration: Srihar(i) Ko Avilok Kai Aanan Io Kah(i) Kai Nrip Baat Sounaaee|| Chhodht Rahialkai Kattee Lau Oupmaa Moukh Kibarninahijaaee||
translation: Seeing Krishna, the king said, “You have got very beautiful hair and the glory of your face is indescribable;

gurmukhi: cwr idpY AKIAwn doaU aupmw n kCU ien qy AiDkweI ] jwhu cly qum kau hir Cwfq lYhu khwN hT Twn lrweI ]1645]
transliteration: Chaar Dipai Akheeaan Do Oupmaa Na Kachhodh In Te Adhikaaee|| Jaahu Chale Toum Kau Har(i) Chhaadat Laihu Kahaan Hath Thaan Laraaee||1645||
translation: “Your eyes are extremely charming and they cannot be compared with anything; O Krishna ! you may go away, I leave you; what will you gain by fighting?” 1645.

gurmukhi: Dnu bwn sMBwr khXo bpuro hmrI bqIXw hirjU suin lIjY ] ikau hiT Twn AXoDn mY hm isau smuhwiekY Awhv kIjY ]
transliteration: Dhan(u) Baan Sanbhaar Kahyo Bapuro Hamribateeyaa Har(i)joo Soun(i) Leejai|| Kio Hath(i) Thaan Ayodhan Mai Ham Sio Samuhaae-kai Aahav Keejai||
translation: Holing his bow and arrows, the king said to Krishna, “You listen to me, why are you coming before me to fight persistently?

gurmukhi: mwrq hoN Ab qoih n Cwfq jwhu Bly Ab lau nhI CIjY ] mwn khXo hmro pur kI kjrwrin ko n biRQw duK dIjY ]1646]
transliteration: Maarat Hon Ab Tohe Na Chhaadat Jaahu Bhale Ab Lau Nahichheejai|| Maan Kahyo Hamro Pur Kikajraaran(i) Ko Na Brithaa Doukh Deejai||1646||
translation: “I shall kill you now and shall not leave you, otherwise you may go away; nothing has gone wrong even now; obey me and do not uselessly put in anguish the women of the city by dying.1646.

gurmukhi: hau hT Twn AXoDn mY Gn sXwm Gny rnbIrin byry ] kw ky khy hm so hir jU smuhwie BXo n iPrXo rn hyry ]
transliteration: Hau Hath Thaan Ayodhan Mai Ghan Syaam Ghane Ranbeerqan(i) Dere|| Kaa Ke Kahe Ham So Har(i) Joo Samuhaae Bhayo Na Phiryo Ran Dere||
translation: “I have killed many warriors engaged in war persistently; O Krishna ! who has instigated you to fight with me?; and you are not running away from the war arena;

gurmukhi: mwro khw Ab qokhu hau krunw Aq hI ijX Awvq myry ] qoko mrXo suin kY iCn mY mir jYhY sKw hir jYqk qyry ]1647]
transliteration: Mdaro Kahaa Ab Tokauh Hau Karounaa At Hijiya Aavat Dere|| Toko Daryo Soun(i) Kai Chhin Mai Mar(i) Jaihai Sakhaa Har(i) Jetak Dere||1647||
translation: “The mercy has arisen in my heart, therefore why should I kill you? hearing about your death all your friends will also die in an instant.”1647.

gurmukhi: hir ieau suin kY Dnu bwn lXo iris kY KVgyS ky swmuih DwXo ] Awvq hI kib sXwm BnY Git kw jug bwnn ju`D mcwXo ]
transliteration: Har(i) Io Soun(i) Kai Dhan(u) Baan Layo Ris(i) Kai Khadgesh Ke Saamuh() Dhaayo|| Oovat Hikabi Syaam Bhanai Ghattee Ka Joog Baanan Juddh Machadyo||
translation: Listening to such a talk, Krishna fell upon Kharag Singh in ire, and according to the poet he continued the war for two gharis (very short period);
